natural problem:
Let $A,$ $B,$ $C$ be the angles of a non-right triangle.  Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} \tan A & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix}.\]
natural solution: Expanding the determinant, we get \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} \tan 1 & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} &= \tan A \begin{vmatrix} \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \tan B \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\

&= \tan A(\tan B \tan C - 1) - (\tan C - 1) + (1 - \tan B) \\ &= \tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2. \end{align}From the tangent addition formula, \[\tan (A + B) = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]But

\[\tan (A + B) = \tan (180^\circ - C) = -\tan C,\]so \[-\tan C = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]Then $-\tan C + \tan A \tan B \tan C = \tan A + \tan B.$  Therefore, \[\tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2 = \boxed{2}.\]

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: real and tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = 180"
and h1 : "A \<noteq> 90"
and h2 : "B \<noteq> 90"
and h3 : "C \<noteq> 90"
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> j. if i = j then tan (if i = 0 then A else if i = 1 then B else C) else 1))) = 2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A,$ $B,$ $C$ be the angles of a non-right triangle.  Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} \tan A & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Expanding the determinant, we get \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} \tan 1 & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} &= \tan A \begin{vmatrix} \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \tan B \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= \tan A(\tan B \tan C - 1) - (\tan C - 1) + (1 - \tan B) \\ &= \tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2. \end{align}From the tangent addition formula, \[\tan (A + B) = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]But
 \[\tan (A + B) = \tan (180^\circ - C) = -\tan C,\]so \[-\tan C = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]Then $-\tan C + \tan A \tan B \tan C = \tan A + \tan B.$  Therefore, \[\tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2 = \boxed{2}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: real and tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = 180"
and h1 : "A \<noteq> 90"
and h2 : "B \<noteq> 90"
and h3 : "C \<noteq> 90"
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> j. if i = j then tan (if i = 0 then A else if i = 1 then B else C) else 1))) = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given three angles A, B, and C of a triangle where none of them is 90 degrees and their sum equals 180 degrees. Calculate the determinant of a 3x3 matrix where the diagonal entries are the tangent of these angles (A, B, C) and all other entries are 1. The final answer is 2.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: real and tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = pi"
and h1 : "A \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h2 : "B \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h3 : "C \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h4 : "\<forall> x. tan x = sin x / cos x"
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>j. if i = j then tan (if i = 0 then A else if i = 1 then B else C) else 1))) = 2"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A,$ $B,$ $C$ be the angles of a non-right triangle.  Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} \tan A & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Expanding the determinant, we get \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} \tan 1 & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} &= \tan A \begin{vmatrix} \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \tan B \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= \tan A(\tan B \tan C - 1) - (\tan C - 1) + (1 - \tan B) \\ &= \tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2. \end{align}From the tangent addition formula, \[\tan (A + B) = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]But
 \[\tan (A + B) = \tan (180^\circ - C) = -\tan C,\]so \[-\tan C = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]Then $-\tan C + \tan A \tan B \tan C = \tan A + \tan B.$  Therefore, \[\tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2 = \boxed{2}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: real and tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = pi"
and h1 : "A \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h2 : "B \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h3 : "C \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h4 : "\<forall> x. tan x = sin x / cos x"
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>j. if i = j then tan (if i = 0 then A else if i = 1 then B else C) else 1))) = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given three angles A, B, and C of a triangle, where none of them is equal to $\pi/2$ and their sum is equal to $\pi$, and the tangent function is defined as the ratio of the sine to the cosine of an angle, compute the determinant of a 3x3 matrix where the diagonal elements are the tangent of the angles A, B, and C (in that order) and all the off-diagonal elements are 1. The final answer is 2.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: real and tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and det :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = pi"
and h1 : "A \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h2 : "B \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h3 : "C \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h4 : "det (tan A) 1 1 1 (tan B) 1 1 1 (tan C) = 2"
shows  "det (tan A) 1 1 1 (tan B) 1 1 1 (tan C) = 2"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A,$ $B,$ $C$ be the angles of a non-right triangle.  Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} \tan A & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Expanding the determinant, we get \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} \tan 1 & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} &= \tan A \begin{vmatrix} \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \tan B \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= \tan A(\tan B \tan C - 1) - (\tan C - 1) + (1 - \tan B) \\ &= \tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2. \end{align}From the tangent addition formula, \[\tan (A + B) = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]But
 \[\tan (A + B) = \tan (180^\circ - C) = -\tan C,\]so \[-\tan C = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]Then $-\tan C + \tan A \tan B \tan C = \tan A + \tan B.$  Therefore, \[\tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2 = \boxed{2}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: real and tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and det :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = pi"
and h1 : "A \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h2 : "B \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h3 : "C \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h4 : "det (tan A) 1 1 1 (tan B) 1 1 1 (tan C) = 2"
shows  "det (tan A) 1 1 1 (tan B) 1 1 1 (tan C) = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: The angles A, B, and C of a triangle add up to π (pi), and none of them are equal to π/2. If the determinant of the 3x3 matrix with the tangent of these angles on the diagonal and all other entries 1 equals 2, confirm that the determinant of this matrix indeed equals 2.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "A \<noteq> 90"
and h1 : "B \<noteq> 90"
and h2 : "C \<noteq> 90"
and h3 : "A + B + C = 180"
shows  "det(matrix([[tan A, 1, 1], [1, tan B, 1], [1, 1, tan C]])) = 2"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A,$ $B,$ $C$ be the angles of a non-right triangle.  Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} \tan A & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Expanding the determinant, we get \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} \tan 1 & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} &= \tan A \begin{vmatrix} \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \tan B \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= \tan A(\tan B \tan C - 1) - (\tan C - 1) + (1 - \tan B) \\ &= \tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2. \end{align}From the tangent addition formula, \[\tan (A + B) = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]But
 \[\tan (A + B) = \tan (180^\circ - C) = -\tan C,\]so \[-\tan C = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]Then $-\tan C + \tan A \tan B \tan C = \tan A + \tan B.$  Therefore, \[\tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2 = \boxed{2}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "A \<noteq> 90"
and h1 : "B \<noteq> 90"
and h2 : "C \<noteq> 90"
and h3 : "A + B + C = 180"
shows  "det(matrix([[tan A, 1, 1], [1, tan B, 1], [1, 1, tan C]])) = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given three different angles A, B, and C in a triangle, none of which are 90 degrees and their sum equals to 180 degrees, calculate the determinant of the matrix formed by [[tan A, 1, 1], [1, tan B, 1], [1, 1, tan C]]. The final answer is 2.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = pi"
and h1 : "A \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h2 : "B \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h3 : "C \<noteq> pi / 2"
shows  "abs([[tan A, 1, 1], [1, tan B, 1], [1, 1, tan C]]) = 2"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A,$ $B,$ $C$ be the angles of a non-right triangle.  Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} \tan A & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Expanding the determinant, we get \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} \tan 1 & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} &= \tan A \begin{vmatrix} \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \tan B \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= \tan A(\tan B \tan C - 1) - (\tan C - 1) + (1 - \tan B) \\ &= \tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2. \end{align}From the tangent addition formula, \[\tan (A + B) = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]But
 \[\tan (A + B) = \tan (180^\circ - C) = -\tan C,\]so \[-\tan C = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]Then $-\tan C + \tan A \tan B \tan C = \tan A + \tan B.$  Therefore, \[\tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2 = \boxed{2}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "A + B + C = pi"
and h1 : "A \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h2 : "B \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h3 : "C \<noteq> pi / 2"
shows  "abs([[tan A, 1, 1], [1, tan B, 1], [1, 1, tan C]]) = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem:
Given that angles A, B, and C are such that A + B + C = π, and none of the angles equals π/2, find the absolute value of the determinant of the matrix 
[[tan A, 1, 1], [1, tan B, 1], [1, 1, tan C]]. The final answer is 2.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "A > 0"
and h1 : "B > 0"
and h2 : "C > 0"
and h3 : "A + B + C = 180"
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>j. if i = j then tan (if i = 0 then A else if i = 1 then B else C) else 1))) = 2"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A,$ $B,$ $C$ be the angles of a non-right triangle.  Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} \tan A & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Expanding the determinant, we get \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} \tan 1 & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} &= \tan A \begin{vmatrix} \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \tan B \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\

 \[\tan (A + B) = \tan (180^\circ - C) = -\tan C,\]so \[-\tan C = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]Then $-\tan C + \tan A \tan B \tan C = \tan A + \tan B.$  Therefore, \[\tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2 = \boxed{2}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "A > 0"
and h1 : "B > 0"
and h2 : "C > 0"
and h3 : "A + B + C = 180"
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>j. if i = j then tan (if i = 0 then A else if i = 1 then B else C) else 1))) = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given three positive angles A, B, C in degrees such that their sum is 180, find the determinant of a 3x3 matrix where each diagonal element is the tangent of one of the angles (with A, B, C respectively from top left to bottom right) and every off-diagonal element is 1. The final answer is 2.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "A \<noteq> 90"
and h1 : "B \<noteq> 90"
and h2 : "C \<noteq> 90"
and h3 : "A + B + C = 180"
shows  "det (Matrix.vec (3::nat) (\<lambda>i. Matrix.vec (3::nat) (\<lambda>j. if (i = 0 \<and> j = 0) then tan A else 
   if (i = 1 \<and> j = 1) then tan B else
   if (i = 2 \<and> j = 2) then tan C else 1))) = 2"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A,$ $B,$ $C$ be the angles of a non-right triangle.  Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} \tan A & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Expanding the determinant, we get \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} \tan 1 & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} &= \tan A \begin{vmatrix} \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \tan B \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= \tan A(\tan B \tan C - 1) - (\tan C - 1) + (1 - \tan B) \\ &= \tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2. \end{align}From the tangent addition formula, \[\tan (A + B) = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]But
 \[\tan (A + B) = \tan (180^\circ - C) = -\tan C,\]so \[-\tan C = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]Then $-\tan C + \tan A \tan B \tan C = \tan A + \tan B.$  Therefore, \[\tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2 = \boxed{2}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "A \<noteq> 90"
and h1 : "B \<noteq> 90"
and h2 : "C \<noteq> 90"
and h3 : "A + B + C = 180"
shows  "det (Matrix.vec (3::nat) (\<lambda>i. Matrix.vec (3::nat) (\<lambda>j. if (i = 0 \<and> j = 0) then tan A else 
   if (i = 1 \<and> j = 1) then tan B else
   if (i = 2 \<and> j = 2) then tan C else 1))) = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given three angles A, B, and C of a triangle, none of which are 90 degrees, and the sum of A, B, and C equals 180 degrees. Determine the determinant of a 3x3 matrix where the diagonal entries are tan(A), tan(B), and tan(C), and all other entries are 1. The final answer is 2.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: real and tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A \<noteq> 90"
and h1 : "B \<noteq> 90"
and h2 : "C \<noteq> 90"
and h3 : "A + B + C = 180"
shows  "det (Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i, j).
  if i = 0 then (if j = 0 then tan A else 1)
  else if i = 1 then (if j = 1 then tan B else 1)
  else (if j = 2 then tan C else 1))) = 2"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A,$ $B,$ $C$ be the angles of a non-right triangle.  Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} \tan A & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Expanding the determinant, we get \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} \tan 1 & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} &= \tan A \begin{vmatrix} \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \tan B \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= \tan A(\tan B \tan C - 1) - (\tan C - 1) + (1 - \tan B) \\ &= \tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2. \end{align}From the tangent addition formula, \[\tan (A + B) = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]But
 \[\tan (A + B) = \tan (180^\circ - C) = -\tan C,\]so \[-\tan C = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]Then $-\tan C + \tan A \tan B \tan C = \tan A + \tan B.$  Therefore, \[\tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2 = \boxed{2}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: real and tan :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A \<noteq> 90"
and h1 : "B \<noteq> 90"
and h2 : "C \<noteq> 90"
and h3 : "A + B + C = 180"
shows  "det (Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i, j).
  if i = 0 then (if j = 0 then tan A else 1)
  else if i = 1 then (if j = 1 then tan B else 1)
  else (if j = 2 then tan C else 1))) = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given three non-right angles A, B, and C in a triangle where the sum of the angles is 180 degrees. Calculate the determinant of a 3x3 matrix where the diagonal elements are the tangent of these angles and all non-diagonal elements are 1. The final answer is 2.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "A \<noteq> 90"
and h1 : "B \<noteq> 90"
and h2 : "C \<noteq> 90"
and h3 : "A + B + C = 180"
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> j. if i = 0 \<and> j = 0 then tan A else if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then tan B else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then tan C else 1))) = 2"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A,$ $B,$ $C$ be the angles of a non-right triangle.  Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} \tan A & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 2

 Expanding the determinant, we get \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} \tan 1 & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} &= \tan A \begin{vmatrix} \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \tan B \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\

 \[\tan (A + B) = \tan (180^\circ - C) = -\tan C,\]so \[-\tan C = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]Then $-\tan C + \tan A \tan B \tan C = \tan A + \tan B.$  Therefore, \[\tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2 = \boxed{2}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "A \<noteq> 90"
and h1 : "B \<noteq> 90"
and h2 : "C \<noteq> 90"
and h3 : "A + B + C = 180"
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> j. if i = 0 \<and> j = 0 then tan A else if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then tan B else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then tan C else 1))) = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given three angles A, B, and C in a triangle, such that none of them are equal to 90 degrees and they sum up to 180 degrees, find the determinant of a 3x3 matrix. This matrix has the tangent of these angles on its diagonal (tan A, tan B, tan C from top left to bottom right) and all other entries are 1. The final answer is 2.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "tan A \<noteq> 0"
and h1 : "tan B \<noteq> 0"
and h2 : "tan C \<noteq> 0"
and h3 : "A + B + C = pi"
and h4 : "A \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h5 : "B \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h6 : "C \<noteq> pi / 2"
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>j. if i = 0 \<and> j = 0 then tan A else if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then tan B else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then tan C else 1))) = 2"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A,$ $B,$ $C$ be the angles of a non-right triangle.  Compute
\[\begin{vmatrix} \tan A & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Expanding the determinant, we get \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} \tan 1 & 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} &= \tan A \begin{vmatrix} \tan B & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1  & 1 \\ 1 & \tan C \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & \tan B \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= \tan A(\tan B \tan C - 1) - (\tan C - 1) + (1 - \tan B) \\ &= \tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2. \end{align}From the tangent addition formula, \[\tan (A + B) = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]But
 \[\tan (A + B) = \tan (180^\circ - C) = -\tan C,\]so \[-\tan C = \frac{\tan A + \tan B}{1 - \tan A \tan B}.\]Then $-\tan C + \tan A \tan B \tan C = \tan A + \tan B.$  Therefore, \[\tan A \tan B \tan C - \tan A - \tan B - \tan C + 2 = \boxed{2}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: real
assumes h0 : "tan A \<noteq> 0"
and h1 : "tan B \<noteq> 0"
and h2 : "tan C \<noteq> 0"
and h3 : "A + B + C = pi"
and h4 : "A \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h5 : "B \<noteq> pi / 2"
and h6 : "C \<noteq> pi / 2"
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>j. if i = 0 \<and> j = 0 then tan A else if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then tan B else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then tan C else 1))) = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given three angles A, B, and C, where none of them are 90 degrees and the sum of them is 180 degrees, find the determinant of the 3x3 matrix where the diagonal elements are the tangent of these angles (tan A, tan B, tan C) and all other elements are 1. The final answer is 2.
